text: hi everyone wreath and he buys Tano here
the internet's busiest music nerd and
it's time for a review of this new album
from spelling and the Mystery school
spelling spelling spelling for those who
are uninitiated what can be said about
spelling it is a West Coast music
project that is spearheaded by composer
songwriter singer producer
multi-instrumentalist Christia Cabral as
spelling with her band she made my
favorite album of 2021 the Turning wheel
a musical experience that sounds like a
radical naturalistic future witch Utopia
which is wrapped in these shiny
perfectly arranged layers of
instrumentation that among many other
reasons is why this record got the rare
privilege of receiving a 10 out of 10
score from me and after a release like
this I presumed it would be a long time
before we heard from spelling again
especially considering all of the
Touring that shortly followed this
record and all the artistic Evolution
Christia had to undergo between this and
her last album Maisy fly if you listen
to both their such incredibly different
records it's crazy that they came from
the same person in such a short span of
time because maisie's sparse and Eerie
dark wave inspired instrumental palettes
are such a far cry away from the
mystical Art Pop of the Turning wheel
and obviously a lot of that change sits
on christia's shoulders and the way she
has evolved as an artist but this
current phase for spelling is also very
much about this new range of instruments
in the mix and don't forget about the
people who play them too which is where
spelling and the Mystery School comes in
because this album isn't just about
Christia recreating the musical world in
her mind this project here is much more
about the creative chemistry she has
with her band the way they've been able
to re-envision certain turning Wheel
tracks since taking them out on the road
and also retool older spelling material
from records that are just much more
stripped back the whole front end of
this album is just reworks of songs from
Maisy fly and Pantheon of me which some
of you may shrug your shoulders at that
and think well what's the big deal these
are just old songs but these new
versions make them worth hearing again I
promise you because Christia and her
band make them sound as ornate and
beautiful as any song off of the Turning
wheel it's just a crazy and kind of
moving Evolution to hear walk up to your
house for example go from this very
simple vocal and synth meditation to
this full display of weepy strings
passionate lead vocals steady Rock drums
the layered vocal chance hit hard too
it's like hearing a new song entirely or
like hearing this one the way it was
originally meant to be done if spelling
had the capability to earlier so there's
that and there's also moments on this
thing like under the sun which honestly
was an amazing single when I first heard
it that track was one of the first that
really kind of hooked me on spelling to
begin with and this new rendition is a
different vibe it sounds less eerie and
less haunted in a way but now now that
it's all decked out in pianos and
strings and driving kicks there's a
fiery and exciting momentum to it that
just kind of gives it new life which I
would also say is the case for they
start the dance there's a sick delay
soaked vocal breakdown at the midpoint
along with a string Crescendo at the
very finish of the song that's nuts
Christie is taking so many creative
liberties with her own material on this
thing it's just sounding super
refreshing radically different and
that's stellar and then there's new
versions of tracks on this thing that
feel a bit more familiar haunted water
for example which very much maintains
it's a very slow intro synth arpeggios
even if it is clearly enhanced it very
much feels like the same song and I love
that it's able to maintain that
familiarity while launching slowly into
this heavy prog leaning ghost rock jam
hard to please is another pretty key
spelling single that is years old at
this point and on this record it's
reimagined in a way that is bright and
hopeful and warm despite the futile
position Christia finds herself in and
at the end of the track where the love
she's singing about seems to be
unrequited still no amount of words can
truly explain how radically different
this Arrangement makes the track feel in
terms of emotional Vibe my least
favorite of the older Cuts featured on
this mystery School record has to be
Cherry which originally was already one
of the more repetitive and
one-dimensional spelling tracks and I
don't think this redo does enough to
bring more variation into the song and
really pull out its full potential now
the final several tracks on this record
are pretty much turning wheel songs that
many fans at this point are already
familiar with boys at school always
Revolution and the closer to the Turning
wheel sweet talk and this is where the
record I believe begins to lose a bit of
direction and purpose because these
songs already kind of represent the new
version and sound of this project
there's not as much retooling to be done
with them however it still does feel
like we're hearing at least some of the
alterations that Christia and the band
have been working on since performing
these songs live look I will say boys at
school should go down as one of the best
songs of this decade Hearing in any
context is great presenting it in a much
more intimate way on this record that
leans a bit less into the synths and
electronics and also brings a punchier
drum performance that's interesting
pretty powerful as well I'm never going
to say no to listening to this track but
then there's always a revolution which
like I said earlier kind of sounds like
some live studio stuff like a kexp or
tiny desk performance or a very small
live show and even though I do
appreciate small additions like the sick
guitar solo on Revolution I I don't know
if I would rather listen to these
versions over the originals in any
context really however I will say this
new rendition of sweet talk is kind of a
surprise hearing the vocals on this one
in a more naked context with a stronger
Rhythm Section and the ascending and
descending Melodies I'm folding in a
somewhat slower and more dramatic way
there is something about that but I
don't know if the song works as well as
a finisher for what is essentially like
a compilation in a way of reworks I
think Small Talk made a lot more sense
as christia's epilogue-esque statement
on her attraction to music itself at the
end of The Turning wheel maybe it's
something emotionally she feels is worth
restating because it still stands as
true at the end of this album but
honestly I would have rather had this

Wheel song or even an older spelling
track uh that got yet again reworked
into something more Grand ambitious and
lavish overall while I may not be in
love with this record I thought it was
an interesting experiment and little
detour for uh Christia spelling the band
I think it captures a really cool little
snapshot in her artistic Evolution for
the fans and it makes me look forward
